short_description: A beloved Korean spicy braised chicken stew featuring bone-in chicken simmered with potatoes and vegetables in a rich, fiery gochugaru and gochujang-based sauce. Also known as Dakbokkeumtang, this comforting one-pot dish is a cornerstone of Korean home cooking, offering the perfect balance of heat, sweetness, and savory depth that warms you from the inside out.
steps: Cut chicken into 8-10 pieces through the bone - you can ask your butcher to do this.
Rinse chicken pieces and pat dry with paper towels.
In a large bowl, prepare the sauce: combine gochugaru, soy sauce, gochujang, minced garlic, grated ginger, rice wine, and sugar.
Mix thoroughly until sugar dissolves and paste is smooth.
Add chicken pieces to the sauce and massage the marinade into the chicken.
Let marinate for at least 20 minutes at room temperature, or up to 2 hours in refrigerator.
While chicken marinates, prepare the vegetables.
Peel potatoes and cut into large 4cm chunks - large pieces won't fall apart during cooking.
Roll-cut carrots into chunky diagonal pieces for even cooking.
Cut onions into thick wedges, keeping the root end intact to hold layers together.
Slice zucchini into thick half-moons.
Cut white parts of green onions into 5cm lengths; thinly slice green parts for garnish.
In a large, heavy-bottomed pot or Korean ttukbaegi, place marinated chicken in a single layer.
Pour any remaining marinade over the chicken.
Add water or stock - it should come about halfway up the chicken.
Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce to medium.
Skim any foam that rises to the surface in the first few minutes.
Add potatoes, carrots, and onion wedges, pushing them down into the liquid.
Cover and simmer for 20 minutes, gently stirring occasionally.
Add white parts of green onions and zucchini.
Continue cooking uncovered for another 15-20 minutes until chicken is cooked through and potatoes are tender.
The sauce should reduce and thicken naturally from the potato starch.
Taste and adjust seasoning - add more soy sauce for saltiness or sugar for sweetness.
Drizzle toasted sesame oil over the stew and stir gently.
Transfer to a serving bowl or serve directly from the pot.
Garnish with sliced green onion tops and toasted sesame seeds.
Serve immediately with plenty of steamed white rice and kimchi.
cooking_tips: Bone-in chicken is essential - the bones add incredible depth and body to the braising liquid.
Cut vegetables large so they don't disintegrate during the long braise.
Gochugaru provides color and mild heat; gochujang adds depth and fermented complexity.
If the stew gets too thick, add a splash of water; if too thin, simmer uncovered to reduce.
Waxy potatoes hold their shape better than starchy ones.
This stew tastes even better the next day as flavors meld - just reheat gently with a splash of water.
nutrition_benefits: Excellent source of lean protein from chicken. Gochugaru contains capsaicin, known to boost metabolism and provide anti-inflammatory benefits. Potatoes offer potassium and vitamin C. Garlic and ginger provide immune-supporting compounds. Sesame oil adds heart-healthy unsaturated fats.
